A multisig VerusID can require up to 13 out of 25 signatures. This allows for a high degree of customizability and flexibility in terms of the number of signatures required to authorize a transaction.

Some possible configurations include: 13 of 25 signatures, which would require a majority of the designated signers to agree; 13 of 13 signatures, which would require all of the designated signers to agree; 1 of 25 signatures, which would allow any one of the designated signers to authorize a transaction; and 1 of 1 signature (which is equivalent to a regular non-multisig wallet), which would not require any additional signatures at all.

These are just a few examples, but the possibilities are endless, and the specific configuration will depend on the needs and preferences of the user or organization creating the multisig VerusID.
How many signatures can a multisig VerusID require, and what are some examples of possible configurations?

A multisig VerusID can require up to 13 out of 25 signatures. Some possible configurations include: 13 of 25 signatures, 13 of 13 signatures, 1 of 25 signatures, and 1 of 1 signature (which is equivalent to a regular non-multisig wallet).

# Set up multisig for VerusID
With multisig, you can set up a wallet that requires multiple signatures to send a transaction.

For example, you could set up a wallet that requires two out of three possible signatures before a transaction can be sent.

A multisig VerusID can be up to **13 of 25 signatures**. It can also be 13 of 13; 1 of 25; and of course 1 of 1.
